move.translation[0].definitions[0].defin: to change from one place or position to another, or to make something do this
move.translation[0].definitions[0].examp: Please keep the doors closed while the train is moving.
‘Come on, ’ Sue said. No one moved.
Could you move your car, please? It’s blocking the road.
The bar was so crowded you could hardly move.
At Christmas, you couldn’t move for toys in this house  (=there were a lot of toys).
Paul couldn’t move a muscle (=could not move at all) he was so scared.
The plane moved slowly along the runway, then stopped.
Becca moved down the steps and into the yard.
I could hear someone moving around upstairs.
move.translation[0].definitions[1].defin: if a person or company moves, or if you move them, they go to live or work in a different place
move.translation[0].definitions[1].examp: We’ve moved seven or eight times in the last five years.
The company is moving its sales center downtown.
My parents kept moving house because of my dad’s job.
When are you moving to Memphis?
They’ve moved into bigger offices in London.
He had to move his mother into a nursing home.
move.translation[0].definitions[2].defin: to change from one opinion or way of thinking to another
move.translation[0].definitions[2].examp: Neither side is willing to move on the issue of territory.
The two political parties have moved closer towards each other in recent months.
At this stage, children move further away from the influence of their parents, and depend more on their friends.
move.translation[0].definitions[3].defin: to persuade someone to change their opinion
move.translation[0].definitions[3].examp: She won’t be moved – it doesn’t matter what you say to her.
move.translation[0].definitions[4].defin: to make progress in a particular way or at a particular rate
move.translation[0].definitions[4].examp: Things moved quickly once the contract was signed.
The negotiations seem to be moving in the right direction.
The plan should boost employment and get things moving in the economy.
move.translation[0].definitions[5].defin: to start taking action, especially in order to achieve something or deal with a problem
move.translation[0].definitions[5].examp: You’ll have to move fast if you want to get a place on the course.
The governor has yet to move on any of the recommendations in the report.
move.translation[0].definitions[6].defin: to change to a different job, class etc, or to make someone change to a different job, class etc
move.translation[0].definitions[6].examp: Several students were moved from the beginners’ class into the intermediate one.
He spent five years at KLP, before moving to IMed as a manager.
move.translation[0].definitions[7].defin: to make someone feel strong emotions, especially of sadness or sympathy
move.translation[0].definitions[7].examp: His speech moved the audience to tears.
Russell was deeply moved by what he heard.
move.translation[0].definitions[8].defin: to cause someone to do something
move.translation[0].definitions[8].examp: Seeing her there had moved him to think about the time they had together.
I have never before felt moved to write, but I feel I must protest.
move.translation[0].definitions[9].defin: to change the time or order of something
move.translation[0].definitions[9].examp: Could we move the meeting to Thursday?
move.translation[0].definitions[10].defi: to start talking or writing about a different subject
move.translation[0].definitions[10].exam: We seem to be moving away from the main point of the discussion.
move.translation[0].definitions[11].defi: to change the position of one of the objects used to play a game such as chess
move.translation[0].definitions[12].defi: to officially make a proposal at a meeting
move.translation[0].definitions[12].exam: They want to move an amendment to the bill.
The chairman moves that the meeting be adjourned.
I move to approve the minutes as read.
move.translation[0].definitions[14].defi: if things of a particular kind are moving, they are being bought, especially at a particular rate
move.translation[0].definitions[14].exam: The highest-priced homes are still moving slowly.
move.translation[0].note_box[0].items[0]: Move belongs to a group of verbs where the same noun can be the subject of the verb or its object
move.translation[0].note_box[0].items[1]: In this sentence, ‘the store’ is the object of move
They moved the store to bigger premises
move.translation[0].note_box[0].items[2]: In this sentence, ‘the store’ is the subject of move
The store moved to bigger premises
move.translation[0].note_box[1].sections: to go to a different place, or change the position of your body
Sarah moved away from the window.
Every time I move I get a pain in my left shoulder.
sway
to move slowly from one side to the other
The branches swayed in the wind.
Donny swayed drunkenly as he walked back to his car.
to move repeatedly from one side to another, with small gentle movements
He rocked backward and forward in his chair.
The boat rocked from side to side with the waves.
wobble
to move unsteadily from side to side
The bike wobbled a bit, but she soon got it under control.
fidget
to keep moving or playing with your fingers, hands, feet etc, because you are bored or nervous
Diana fidgeted nervously with her pencil.
squirm
to make very small movements from side to side with your body, especially because you feel uncomfortable
By the end of the hour, most of the children were squirming in their seats.
wriggle
to make small movements from side to side, especially in order to get into or out of something
The dog wriggled under the fence and escaped into the street.
She managed to wriggle into the dress, but it was much too tight.
twitch
if part of your body twitches, it makes small movements that you cannot control
A muscle on Yang’s face twitched.
stir
to make a movement – used especially when describing a situation in which no one moves, or someone wakes up
In the village a dog barked but no one stirred.
The sleeping child stirred and opened her eyes.
budge
to move – used when you are trying hard to make something move, often without success
The piano wouldn’t budge.
to move to a different house, office etc
to move to a different house, office etc
They’ve moved back to Santiago.
My brother’s helping us move house.
relocate
to move to a different place – used about companies, organizations, and people who work for them
NATO’s main headquarters relocated to Brussels.
Klein is relocating to London to head up the investment banking team.
not moving
still
not moving – use this especially about people who are not moving, or about places where there is no wind
There was no wind and the trees were completely still.
Keep still while I tie your shoes.
stationary
not moving – use this about cars, trains, or objects
The truck swerved and hit a stationary vehicle.
immobile
not moving or not able to move, especially because of fear or tiredness
As the disease progressed, she became increasingly immobile.
motionless
completely still – used especially in literature
Kemp sat motionless as the verdict was read.
not moving because there is no wind – use this about air and water
The lake was calm.
be at a standstill
if traffic is at a standstill it is not moving
Traffic was at a standstill on the motorway.
move.translation[1].definitions[0].defin: something that you decide to do in order to achieve something
move.translation[1].definitions[0].examp: She’s still thinking about her next move.
Most of the council members are reluctant to make such a drastic move.
The authorities have made no move to resolve the conflict.
Taking the position was a good career move (=a decision that will improve the type of jobs you can do).
She decided to learn as much about it as she could, which seemed like a wise move.
It seems there could be moves afoot to close the centre.
there are moves afoot (to do something)
the Board’s recent moves to cut interest rates
move.translation[1].definitions[1].defin: when someone moves for a short time in a particular direction
move.translation[1].definitions[1].examp: Good gymnasts rehearse their moves mentally before a competition.
He made no move to come any nearer.
Martin made a move towards the door.
One false move (=move in the wrong direction) and I’ll shoot.
His green eyes followed Cissy’s every move.
move.translation[1].definitions[2].defin: a change, especially one which improves a situation
move.translation[1].definitions[2].examp: Much more research is being done, which is a move in the right direction.
a move away from traditional industries such as coal mining
move.translation[1].definitions[3].defin: when you change the position of one of the objects in a game such as chess
move.translation[1].definitions[3].examp: Several moves later, Ron took his king.
It’s your move, Janet  (=it is your turn to move an object).
move.translation[1].definitions[4].defin: when you leave one house, office etc, and go to live or work in a different one
move.translation[1].definitions[4].examp: The move to a larger office building is long overdue.
move.translation[1].note_box[0].heading: – Meaning 1: something that you decide to do in order to achieve something
move.translation[1].note_box[0].sections: make a move
We made the move mainly for financial reasons.
make no move
The government made no move to hold the promised elections.
welcome the move
Environmentalists welcomed the move to limit the length of fishing nets.
oppose a move
Union members have opposed the move.
support a move
The move was supported by the government.
a move is aimed at doing something/is designed to do something
The move is aimed at strengthening its business in the region.
ADJECTIVES/NOUN + move
an important move
I cannot decide on such an important move on my own.
a bold/daring move
The writers made a bold move by killing off the main character.
a good/smart/wise move
I’m not sure it was a good move giving him the job.
the right move
He hoped he had made the right move in telling his father.
an unprecedented move
Barcelona began the unprecedented move of shipping in drinking water.
somebody’s next move
What should happen next? What’s our next move?
a bad move
It was a bad move letting him come here in the first place.
a false/wrong move
One wrong move and the business might never recover.
the first move
She waited for Michael to make the first move.
a career move
It looked like a good career move, with the possibility of promotion later.
there are moves afoot to do something
There are moves afoot to change things.
a move in the right direction
The decision seemed to be a move in the right direction.
move.translation[1].note_box[1].heading: – Meaning 2: when someone moves for a short time in a particular direction
move.translation[1].note_box[1].sections: She made a move towards the door.
He made no move to stop her.
His eyes followed Cissy’s every move.
One false move, and she’d fall over the edge.
She made a sudden move towards me from the doorway.
move.translation[2].definitions[0].defin: if a product moves, or if a shop, dealer etc moves it, it sells very quickly
move.translation[2].definitions[0].examp: These computer games are moving very fast. The kids love them.
The company isn’t moving enough product.
move.translation[2].definitions[1].defin: to change to a different job, department etc, or to make someone change to a different job, department etc
move.translation[2].definitions[1].examp: She’s just moved from the sales department.
move.translation[2].definitions[2].defin: to officially make a suggestion at a meeting
move.translation[2].definitions[2].examp: The chairman moved that the meeting be adjourned.
move.translation[2].definitions[3].defin: to go to live or work in a different place
move.translation[2].definitions[3].examp: When are you moving to Memphis?
They’ve moved into a bigger office.
